taxon_identification.taxon_hierarchy: family rosaceae;tribe rubeae;genus rubus;subgenus eubatus;section arguti;

key_statement.statement: Upper 3 leaflets of fully developed primocane-leaves twice to thrice as long as broad, acuminate2.
Teeth (or many of them) of primocane-and floricane-leaflets simply sharp-serrate, the longer ones 3-6 mm. long
Teeth (or most of them) of primocane-and floricane-leaflets doubly serrate and rarely more than 2-4 mm. long3.
Primocane-leaflets mostly 5 (or 7), acuminate; floricane-leaflets mostly acuminate4.
Lower surfaces of primocane-and floricane-leaflets densely velvety or soft-pubescent to touch.
Larger primocane-leaflets, bracteal leaves or terminal leaflets mostly only one-third as broad as long; fruit amber-white
Larger primocane-leaflets two-fifths to half as broad as long; simple bracts or terminal bracteal leaflets two-fifths to three-fifths as broad as long; fruit purple-black
Lower surfaces of primocane-and floricane-leaflets sparsely pilose to glabrescent, hard (not velvety) to touch
Primocane-leaflets mostly 3, these and floricane-leaflets merely acute or acutish
Upper leaflets of fully developed primocane-leaves mostly less than twice as long as broad5.
Primary inflorescences cylindric racemes, not broadened across the top6.
Terminal (and usually the lower) primocane-leaflets with continuous margin, not lobulate7.
.Leaves densely tomentose beneath, velvety to touch; pedicels, rachis, etc. villous or tomentose; expanding leaves of primocane-tip white-tomentose8.
Terminal leaflet of 5-foliolate leaves oblong-to elliptic-ovate, only slightly more than half as broad as long, gradually long-attenuate, glabrous or promptly glabrate above; fruit 1-1.5 cm. thick.
Ribs of leaves slender, often hidden and not prominent beneath; longer pedicels of leading racemes filiform, 2-5 cm. long; fruit globose, about 1 cm. long
Ribs strong and conspicuous beneath; longer pedicels stoutish, 0.5-2 cm. long, unarmed; fruit short-cylindric, about 1.5 cm. long
Terminal leaflet of 5-foliolate leaves broadly cordate-or subcordate-ovate, much more than half as broad as long, abruptly acuminate9
Leaves strigose-pilose above; pedicels stoutish; corolla 3.5-4 cm. broad; fruit becoming 2-3 cm. long, of rich quality.
Calyx-lobes spreading or only slightly arched-recurving at and after anthesis; fruit subglobose; erect or high-arching shrub of N.S., N.E. and L.I
Calyx-lobes abruptly reflexed at and after anthesis; fruit ellipsoid to thimble-shaped; intricate shrub, with arching branches nearly reaching the ground, of N.Y. to Mich., s. to mts. of nw. N.J
Leaves glabrous above; pedicels filiform; corolla 2 cm. broad; fruit globose, 1 cm. long; western.
Leaves membranaceous, their veins not prominent beneath; terminal primocane-leaflet on petiolule 4-6 cm. long; raceme much elongate, its lower pedicels 3-4.5 cm. long; mid-and north-western
Leaves becoming hard and coriaceous, their veins very prominent beneath; terminal primocane-leaflet on petiolule 1-3 cm. long; raceme short, its lowest pedicels up to 2 cm. long; southwestern

Leaves in maturity merely slightly pilose beneath and not velvety to touch (mature no. 178 might be sought here); expanding leaves merely gray-green; terminal primocane-leaflet cordate-or subcordate-ovate.
Pedicels mostly unarmed, the longer ones 3-5 cm. long; longer racemes 12-20-fi.owered; petiolule of terminal primocane-leaflet 3-4.5cm. long
Pedicels prickly, the longer ones 3 cm. long; racemes 8-10-flowered;petiolule of terminal primocane-leaflet 2 cm. long
Terminal (and often other) primocane-leaflets angulate-lobulate.
Prickles subulate; primocane-leaves 5-foliolate; plants of W.Va. or Ky.
Racemes of lateral branches solitary, compact; the pedicels mostly exceeded by the bracts
Racemes of lateral branches numerous, subpaniculately disposed, loose and open; pedicels much exceeding bracts
Prickles deltoid, broad-based; primocane-leaflets 3 or 5; plant of s.-centr. N.Y
Primary inflorescence subcorymbose-racemose, with short axis, corym-bosely broadened across the top; or flowers only 1-3 at tips of branches10.
.Flowers (l-)2-several in well-developed inflorescences11.
Margin of terminal primocane-leaflet continuous, not lobulate, with relatively short teeth and shallow sinuses (mostly 1-5 mm. deep)12.
Canes becoming woody, up to 3 m. high, stout or slender, erect or ascending, mostly prickly; terminal primocane-leaflets (3.5-)6-20 cm. long; corollas 2-3.5 cm. broad; fruits mostly 1-3 cm. long13
.Most of the pedicels subtended by small stipule-like bracts (all or nearly all foliaceous in an aberrant form of no. 184); large foliaceous bracts usually only 1-3 or 414.
Pedicels all or nearly all unarmed (occasionally 1 or 2 of them slightly armed); veins of primocane-leaves not strongly impressed above; fruit usually of good quality15.
Bracteal leaves or leaflets prevailingly acute; terminal primocane-leaflet definitely longer than broad, often long-acuminate16.
Terminal primocane-leaflet ovate to elliptic, with rounded to cordate base.
Primocane-leaves (except lowest) mostly 5-foliolate and quite unlike leaves of flowering shoots; terminal leaflet acuminate; wide-ranging, through most of our area
Primocane-leaves mostly 3-foliolate, resembling foliage of flowering shoots; terminal leaflet elliptic, merely acutish; low (up to 6 dm.) shrub of e. Md
Terminal primocane-leaflet rhombic-obovate, cuneate at base; small-leaved plant of Md

Bracteal leaves or leaflets mostly obtuse, elliptic-oblong to oblong-obovate; terminal primocane-leaflet round-ovate or obovate, abruptly tipped, about four-fifths as broad as long; tangled shrub with pendulous branchlets, of coast of s. N.E. and N.Y.187
Pedicels all or nearly all strongly armed; subcoriaceous small leaves with straightish nerves impressed above; fruit poor, often bitter; stiff shrub of N.E.188. R. barbarus.
Most (at least more than half) of the pedicels subtended by foliaceous bracts17.

Stouter parts of primocane with 4 or more rows of broad-based (4-6 mm.) often crowded or approximate booked prickles in groups rarely 1 cm. apart; intricately brandling canes with long-arching and tip-trailing branchlets; shrub of s. N.E
Primocanes with scattered and usually straighter or more slender prickles; branchlets not usually trailing18
Foliaceous bracts of leading inflorescences 7-12, subtending all or nearly all pedicels.
Simple bracteal leaves narrowly ovate to lanceolate, long-attenuate; pedicels unarmed; eastern
Simple bracteal leaves broadly ovate to reniform, lobulate, short-pointed; pedicels armed; northwestern
Foliaceous bracts of leading inflorescences fewer, subtending only the lower and median pedicels19.
Primocanes soon forming long-arching or doming shrubs with drooping to tip-trailing branches and branchlets20.
Larger bracts or terminal leaflets of bracts mostly 4-7 cm. long.
Upper flowers equaled or overtopped by the foliaceous bracts; prickles of primocane subulate, nearly straight; wide-ranging
Upper flowers greatly overtopping the foliaceous bracts; prickles of primocane broad-based and hooked; southeastern
Larger bracts or terminal leaflets of bracts 1.5-2.5 cm. long; pedicels mostly overtopping the bracts; shrub of se. cypress-swamps.192. R. cupressorum.
Primocanes stiffly erect or but slightly arching at summit21.
Terminal primocane-leaflets 7-10 cm. long; larger bracts or their terminal leaflets 4-6 cm. long; corymbs 3-12-flowered; pedicels glandless; shrubs of the interior.
Terminal primocane-leaflet ovate, broadest toward base; prickles of primocane subulate or acicular
Terminal primocane-leaflet oblong-elliptic, broadest near middle; prickles broad-based

Terminal primocane-leaflet 4-7 cm, long; larger bracts or their terminal leaflets 1.5-3.5 cm. long; corymbs 2-4-fiowered; pedicels often bearing some short glands; small plants of southeastern states.
Floricanes 2-7 dm. high, with strongly ascending branches, erect; leaflets of floricane ovate, acute
Floricanes 0.6-1.5 m. high, with widely divergent to horizontal branches, arching above; leaflets of floricane narrowly cuneate-obovate or -subrhombic, bluntish

Canes subherbaceous or weak and very slender, not strongly woody hi age, 1.5-5 mm. in diameter, 0.2-1 (-1.5) m. high; terminal primocane-leaflets mostly 4-9 (-11) cm. long; corollas 1.5-2 cm. broad; fruit 0.7-1.5 cm. long. (no. 195 and slender plants of other preceding species might be looked for here)22.
Terminal primocane-leaflet broadly cordate-ovate, nearly as broad as long, the larger ones 7-11 cm. long.
Leaves serrate-dentate, the teeth of primocane-leaves often as broad as long; canes unarmed or with very remote subulate prickles
Leaves sharply serrate, the teeth longer than broad; canes with several prickles per dm
Terminal primocane-leaflet scarcely cordate, more narrowly ovate, definitely longer than broad, 4-9 cm. long.
Leaflets of primocane-foliage and blades or leaflets of bracts sharp-pointed, with prominent and very sharp teeth
Leaflets of primocane-foliage and blades or leaflets of bracts only acute or acutish, with small and merely acute or acutish teeth
Margin of terminal primocane-leaflet rather definitely but irregularly 1-âˆž-lobulate, with often deep sinuses23.
Primocane-leaflets prevailingly 524.

Preponderant inflorescences exceeded by or nearly equaled by the numerous bracteal leaves; canes or their branches and branch-lets soon arching or recurving, the tips nearly or quite reaching the ground and sometimes tip-rooting
Preponderant inflorescences with most of the pedicels raised or borne well above the 1-3 basal bracteal leaves; canes not long-arching nor with branches reaching the ground.
Canes terete; terminal primocane-leaflet subrhombic; most flowers borne high above bracteal leaves
Canes angled; terminal primocane-leaflet tapering from cordate-ovate base; bracts of lower pedicels exceeding the inflorescence
Primo cane-leaflets prevailingly 3; terminal primocane-leaflet round-ovate
Flower solitary on an erect strongly armed axillary pedicel; primocane-leaves 3-foliolate; small erect plant with simple floricane; southeastern
